title: How to Organize a Basement

steps.headline: Separate your belongings into piles.
steps.description: These can be piles such as things to keep, donate, recycle, or throw out. Think carefully about each item, making sure that you’re truly going to use the item if you’re choosing to keep it. If you haven’t used an item in several years or are just keeping it in case you need it in the future, it’s likely safe to get rid of the item. Things like unused books or clothing can be donated or recycled, while things that don’t have a way to be repurposed can be thrown out.

steps.headline: Sell items you no longer need to make some money.
steps.description: There are lots of ways you can sell your items, from posting them online on sites like Craigslist, eBay, or Facebook Marketplace, to hosting your own yard sale. Come up with fair prices for the belongings you’re trying to sell and see what you’re able to get rid of! If you’re posting your belongings for sale online, take good quality photos of each item so people know what they’re buying. Post signs for a yard sale and let friends, neighbors, and family members know in case they’d like to come or sell things too.

steps.headline: Donate or recycle items that can still be used by someone else.
steps.description: Donating items that are still in good condition to charities, thrift stores, or other local organizations is a great way to declutter your basement while helping out the community. Contact local organizations to see what types of things they take. Drop off your items at a local Goodwill or Salvation Army. Some local charities even have a pickup option for pieces of furniture or larger loads of donations.

steps.headline: Throw away items that can’t be repurposed.
steps.description: If you have things in your basement that just can’t be used again, it’s time to throw them out. Put all of your things that are going in the trash in a heavy-duty trash bag and take the bag out to the curb to be picked up with the rest of your garbage. If you have items that won’t fit in a trash bag, you may need to visit your local dump or look into having the dump pick up your trash for you.

steps.headline: Reorganize your keep pile into new categories.
steps.description: Once you’re left with the items you’ll be keeping in the basement, you can create more specific piles for similar items. For example, put all of your books in one pile, sports equipment in another pile, and clothing in another. Reorganizing the things you’re keeping into smaller piles will help you see how many storage containers you might need and how to organize the items you have left. You might have a media pile with things like DVDs, CDs, or gaming equipment. Create groups like arts and crafts or holiday decorations.

steps.headline: Separate the basement into specific zones for your belongings.
steps.description: For example, part of your basement might be a living area with furniture and a television, while the other section is just for storage. If your basement has more than one purpose, it’s important to separate your belongings so that they each have a space. Things like games or books can be stored in a living area, while things like holiday decorations, old clothing, or memorabilia can be placed in the storage section.

steps.headline: Store similar items together so you can easily find them.
steps.description: There’s nothing worse than opening a storage bin to find a random assortment of items that don’t belong together. Make sure your items all belong in the same grouping, such as outdoor gear, arts and crafts, or old furniture that needs storing.

steps.headline: Use plastic bins for sturdy, waterproof storage.
steps.description: Plastic bins are the best choice for your basement, as they come in lots of different sizes and will protect your items from water, humidity, and most other factors that might damage them. Place grouped items into each plastic bin, securing the lid before storing it. Off-season clothing stores well in plastic storage bins, as do craft supplies, shoes, or linens.

steps.headline: Place items in wire baskets for easy access.
steps.description: If you’re storing something in your basement that you’ll use often, putting it in a wire basket allows you to easily pull it out and put it back in without much hassle. Have separate baskets for things like games, blankets, or pool toys. You might have baskets to separate a larger section such as arts and crafts, putting things like yarn, craft paper, paints, and sewing supplies each in their own basket.

steps.headline: Hang hooks to save space and keep things off the floor.
steps.description: Hooks come in all different sizes and strengths, letting you hang a variety of different items on your walls. Check the weight of each item you intend to hang, especially if it’s heavy, to make sure you have the right hooks. Things like bikes, tools, and yard equipment are great items to hang. Use a pegboard to turn a wall into a tool box to hang your tools. When you purchase hooks, the weight they’re able to hold should be stated on the packaging. Utilize hanging racks for clothing and coats as part of your basement organization.

steps.headline: Install sturdy shelving to hold bins, baskets, or other storage.
steps.description: It’s important that your shelving is able to hold heavy amounts of weight and withstand the climate of your basement. Metal shelves are a great option as they’re sturdy, won’t disintegrate, and some even come with wheels making it easy to move them if necessary. Choose shelving that will fit the type of storage you have, whether it’s large plastic bins or smaller baskets. Cube cubbies are a good option for separating your belongings into organized sections. Look for shelving that comes off of the ground⁠—if your basement ever floods, you don’t want your things to be ruined.

steps.headline: Label each box, bin, or basket so you know what’s inside.
steps.description:
Purchase labels from a store that you can write on with permanent marker, or cut out your own before taping them onto the sides of bins, boxes, and baskets. Even if you’re using clear storage bins, labeling each storage container will make it much easier to find what you’re looking for and stay organized. For example, label a basket full of scissors, pencils, erasers, and lined paper as “school supplies.”
Keep extra storage containers and labels handy. If you don't have any labels, place a piece of tape on the basket or bin and write directly on the tape.

steps.headline: Put things away immediately to avoid creating clutter.
steps.description: When you go to your basement and take something out of a container or off of a hook, it’s super important that you return the item back as soon as you’re done. If you don’t, your items will stack up again without a home, and you’ll have to spend time reorganizing the clutter. Labeling your containers and making sure everything has a specific home will make returning things back to their bins, baskets, or hooks much easier and faster.

steps.headline: Avoid having things loose on the floor.
steps.description: Not only does having items laying on the floor look cluttered, but items left on the floor of your basement are in danger of becoming damaged. If you see an item loose on the floor, whether it’s a bike helmet, jacket, or piece of equipment, try to hang it on a hook or put it up on a shelf to keep it out of harm’s way.

steps.headline: Take inventory of your belongings once a year.
steps.description: Every year or two it’s helpful to go to your basement and just see what’s down there⁠—you may be able to get rid of things you haven’t used in a while, or you may need to create storage space for new items. Make sure everything is grouped with similar items and labeled to ensure your basement is organized and clean.
